reference_books: VikramPudi and P. Radha Krishna, Data Mining: 1st Edition, Oxford Publisher, 2009.
Arun K Pujari, Data Mining Techniques, 3rd edition, Universities Press, 2013.

course_outcomes: Understand the concepts related to network categories, topologies, and reference models.
Analyze error and flow control mechanisms in data link layer
Analyse subnetting and various routing protocols of network layer
Analyze transport layer and application layer protocols for specific applications.

syllabus.title: Introduction and Physical Layer
syllabus.topics: Network Types, LAN, MAN, WAN, Network Topologies Reference models- The OSI Reference Model- the TCP/IP Reference Model- A Comparison of the OSI and TCP/IP Reference Models, OSI Vs TCP/IP. Physical Layer:Introduction to Guided Media- Twisted-pair cable, Coaxial cable and Fiber optic cable and introduction about unguided media.

syllabus.title: Data Link Layer
syllabus.topics: Design issues, Framing, flow control, error control, error detection and correction codes, CRC, Checksum. Elementary Data Link Layer protocols. Sliding window protocol: One bit, Go back N, Selective repeat-Stop and wait protocol, Data link layer in HDLC, Point to point protocol (PPP). Media Access Control: Random Access, Controlled Access, Channelization. Wired LANs: Ethernet Protocol, Standard, Fast, Gigabit, and 10 Gigabit Ethernet.

syllabus.title: Network Layer
syllabus.topics: Network Layer Design Issues, Routing Algorithms (Optimality principle, Shortest path, Flooding, Distance vector, Link state, Hierarchical), Congestion Control algorithms. Internet Working: Tunneling, internetwork routing, Fragmentation. Network layer in the internet: IP protocols, IP Version 4 protocol, IPV4 Header Format, IP addresses, Class full Addressing, CIDR, Subnets, IP Version 6, Transition from IPV4 to IPV6.

syllabus.title: Transport and Application Layers
syllabus.topics: The Transport Layer: Transport layer protocols: Introduction-services- port number-User data gram protocol-User datagram-UDP services-UDP applications. Transmission control protocol: TCP services- TCP features- Segment- A TCP connection windows in TCP- flow control-Error control, Congestion control in TCP. Application Layer: World Wide Web: HTTP, Electronic mail, TELENET, Domain Name System.

textbooks: Andrew S Tanenbaum, David J Wetherall, Computer Networks, 5th Edition, Pearson Education, 2011.
Behrouz A.Fourozan, Data Communications and Networking. 4th Edition, TATA McGraw Hill, 2007.
reference_books: J.F. Kurose and K. W. Ross, Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet, 6th Edition, Pearson Education, 2012.

course_outcomes: Understand the basic concepts of formal languages of finite automata techniques.
Apply regular expressions to various problems and minimize the finite automata.
Apply various languages to construct context free grammar, normal forms, PDA.
Analyze a Turing machine and Post’s Correspondence problems.

syllabus.title: Finite Automata
syllabus.topics: Need of Automata theory, Central Concepts, Automation, Finite Automation, Transition Systems, DFA, Design of DFAs, NFA, Design of NFA, Equivalence of DFA and NFA, Conversion of NFA into DFA, Finite Automata with E-Transitions, Minimization of Finite Automata, Finite Automata with output-Mealy and Moore Machines.

syllabus.title: Regular Expressions and Grammars
syllabus.topics: Regular Expressions, Regular Sets, Identity Rules, Equivalence of two RE, Manipulations of REs, Finite Automata and Regular Expressions, Inter Conversion, Pumping Lemma of Regular Sets, Closure Properties of Regular Sets, Grammars, Classification of Grammars, Chomsky Hierarchy Theorem, Right and Left Linear Regular Grammars, Equivalence between RG and FA.

syllabus.title: Context-Free Grammars and Pushdown Automata
syllabus.topics: Formal Languages, Context Free Grammar, Leftmost and Rightmost Derivations, Parse Trees, Ambiguous Grammars, Simplification of Context Free Grammars (Elimination of Useless Symbols, E-Productions and Unit Productions), Normal Forms (Chomsky Normal Form and Greibach Normal Form), Pumping Lemma, Closure Properties. Pushdown Automata: Definition, Model, Graphical Notation, Language Acceptance, Design.

syllabus.title: Advanced Automata Theory
syllabus.topics: Deterministic and Non– Deterministic Pushdown Automata, Equivalence of Pushdown Automata and Context Free Grammars, Two Stack Pushdown Automata. Turing Machine: Definition, Model, Representation, Language of a TM, Design of TMs, Types of TMs, Church’s Thesis, Universal and Restricted TM, Decidable and Un-decidable Problems, Halting Problem of TMs, Post’s Correspondence Problem.

textbooks: J. E. Hopcroft, R. Motwani and J. D. Ullman, Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages and Computation, 3rd Edition, Pearson, 2008.
K. L. P. Mishra and N. Chandrasekharan, Theory of Computer Science-Automata, Languages and Computation, 3rd Edition, PHI, 2007.
reference_books: Lewis H.P., Papadimition C.H., Elements of Theory of Computation, Pearson, PHI, 2015.
V. Kulkarni, Theory of Computation, Oxford University Press, 2013.
Rajendrakumar, Theory of Automata, Languages and Computation, McGraw Hill, 2014.

options: 12 week MOOCs Swayam/NPTEL course recommended by the BoS

course_outcomes: Design techniques of data warehousing and data mining.
Apply various pre-processing techniques on datasets using Data mining techniques.
Analyze classification and apriori algorithms to solve real life problems.
Analyze different types of clustering algorithms to solve real life problems.

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Creation of a Data Warehouse (Build DW/Data Mart, design schemas, write ETL scripts, perform OLAP operations).
Task 2: Explore machine learning tool 'WEKA' (Interface, options, arff file format, load datasets).
Task 3: Perform data preprocessing tasks and Demonstrate performing association rule mining on data sets.
Task 4: Demonstrate performing classification on data sets Weka/R.
Task 5: Demonstrate performing clustering of data sets.
Task 6: Demonstrate knowledge flow application on data sets into Weka/R.
Task 7-16: Implement various data mining and ML algorithms (ZeroR, Apriori, Naive Bayesian, k-means) and techniques (chi-square, dissimilarity matrix, visualization) using Java/Python/R.

textbooks: Jiawei Han, Michel Kamber, Data Mining concepts and Techniques, 3rd edition, Elsevier, 2011.
Pang-Ning Tan & Michael Steinbach, Vipin Kumar, Introduction to Data Mining, 2nd edition, Pearson, 2012.
reference_books: VikramPudi and P. Radha Krishna, Data Mining, 1st Edition, Oxford Publisher.
Arun K Pujari, Data Mining Techniques, 3rd edition, Universities Press, 2013.

course_outcomes: Analyze working of Reference models in action.
Analyse protocols at Data Link Layer.
Apply IPv4 and IPv6 addressing schemes for the given network and troubleshoot issues.
Analyse the security measures implemented in networks.

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Investigate OSI and TCP reference models in action.
Task 2: Implement data link layer framing methods (Character stuffing, bit stuffing).
Task 3: Implement data link layer error control methods (checksum, CRC).
Task 4: Implement Hamming Code for error detection and correction.
Task 5: Basic Switch and End Device Configuration.
Task 6: Implement Sliding window protocol for Goback N and for Selective repeat.
Task 7: IPv4 Addressing (Subnetting, VLSM).
Task 8: Implement Stop and Wait Protocol.
Task 9: Implement congestion control using leaky bucket algorithm.
Task 10: Implement Dijkstra‘s algorithm for Shortest path.
Task 11: Implement Distance vector routing algorithm.
Task 12: Implement Broadcast tree.
Task 13: Packet Capture Using Wireshark.
Task 14: Use Ping and Traceroute to Test Network Connectivity.
Task 15: Run Nmap scan and Operating System Detection.
Task 16: Configure Secure Passwords and SSH.

textbooks: Andrew S Tanenbaum, David J Wetherall, Computer Networks, 5th Edition, Pearson Education, 2011.
Behrouz A.Fourozan, Data Communications and Networking. 4th Edition, TATA McGraw Hill, 2007.
reference_books: J.F. Kurose and K. W. Ross, Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet, 6th Edition, Pearson Education, 2012.

course_outcomes: Implement router, template engine and authentication using sessions to develop application in ExpressJS.
Build a single page application using RESTful APIs in ExpressJS
Apply router and hooksin designing ReactJS application
Implement MongoDB queries to perform CRUD operations on document database

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. ExpressJS: Routing, HTTP Methods, Middleware.
2. ExpressJS: Templating, Form Data.
3. ExpressJS: Cookies, Sessions, Authentication.
4. ExpressJS: Database connection (MongoDB) and RESTful APIs.
5. ReactJS: Render HTML, JSX, Function & Class Components.
6. ReactJS: Props, States, Styles, and Event Handling.
7. ReactJS: Conditional Rendering, Rendering Lists, and React Forms.
8. ReactJS: React Router for page navigation.
9. ReactJS: Using Hooks and sharing data between components.
10. MongoDB: Installation, Configuration, and CRUD operations.
11. MongoDB: Working with Databases, Collections, and Records.
12. Augmented Programs: Design a to-do list app and a quiz app.

textbooks: Vasan Subramanian, Pro MERN Stack: Full Stack Web App Development with Mongo, Express, React, and Node, 2nd edition, APress, O’Reilly.
Mike Cantelon, Mark Harter, T.J. Holowaychuk, Nathan Rajlich, Node.Js in Action, Manning Publications. (Chapters 1-11)
AzatMardan, React Quickly, Manning Publications, 2nd Edition, 2017.

course_outcomes: Identify the Societal problems.
Solve the problems.
Design of the problem/work plan.
Design of the prototype/model.

syllabus.title: Project Description
syllabus.topics: Carried out during summer vacation for six weeks after Semester 4. Students will go to the society (Villages/ Hospitals/Towns, etc,.) to identify a problem, survey literature for a feasible solution, and are encouraged to solve real life problems leading to innovative model building. This can be done in a group of students or as an individual.

course_outcomes: Execute rational pronunciation of speech sounds including accentuation.
Apply elements of listening comprehension in professional environments.
Develop the abilities of rational argumentation and skills of public speaking.
Demonstrate proficiency in the elements of professional communication including the competitive examination.

syllabus.title: Spoken Expression and Listening Comprehension
syllabus.topics: Speech Mechanism, Articulation of vowels and consonants, Patterns of Accentuation, Types and processes of Listening comprehension.

syllabus.title: Public Speaking
syllabus.topics: Group Discussion(Open and Monitored), Pyramid Discussion, PNI, Seminar Talk and Power Point Presentation.

syllabus.title: Professional Communication
syllabus.topics: Self Affirmation Advanced Composition including Memo and e-mail, Resume Preparation, Corporate ethic of Non-Verbal Communication.

syllabus.title: Life Skills and Vocabulary for Competitive Examinations
syllabus.topics: Select Life Skills(50), Select Logies, Isms, Phobias and Manias (25 each), Sentence Completion and Double Unit Verbal Analogies (50 items), Fundamentals of Syllogisms(Descriptive and Pictorial).

textbooks: M. Cutts, Oxford Guide to Plain English, 7th impression, Oxford, UK: Oxford University Press, 2011.

Department of Phonetics and Spoken English, Exercises in Spoken English, 21st impression, Hyderabad, India: Central Institute of English and Foreign Languages (CIEFL), published by Oxford University Press, 2003.
reference_books: S. R. Covey, The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, 2nd edition, London, UK: Simon & Schuster UK Ltd (Pocket Books), 2004.
J. S. Brubacher, Eclectic Philosophy of Education: A Book of Readings, Englewood Cliffs, NJ, USA: Prentice-Hall, 1951.

course_outcomes: Learns to Implement Flutter Widgets and Layouts
Understand Responsive UI Design and with Navigation in Flutter
Knowledge on Widges and customize widgets for specific UI elements, Themes
Understand to include animation apart from fetching data

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. Install Flutter and Dart SDK.
2. Explore Flutter widgets (Text, Image, Container) and implement layouts (Row, Column, Stack).
3. Design a responsive UI that adapts to different screen sizes using media queries.
4. Set up navigation between screens using Navigator and named routes.
5. Learn about stateful/stateless widgets and implement state management using setState and Provider.
6. Create custom widgets and apply styling using themes.
7. Design a form with various input fields and implement validation.
8. Add animations to UI elements.
9. Fetch data from a REST API and display it in the UI.
10. Write unit tests and use debugging tools.

textbooks: M. L. Napoli, Beginning Flutter: A Hands-on Guide to App Development, Hoboken, NJ, USA: John Wiley & Sons, 2020.
R. Payne, Beginning App Development with Flutter: Create Cross-Platform Mobile Apps, 1st edition, New York, NY, USA: Apress, 2021.
R. Rose, Flutter & Dart Cookbook: Developing Full-Stack Applications for the Cloud, Sebastopol, CA, USA: O’Reilly Media, 2022.

course_outcomes: Understand the corporate etiquette.
Make presentations effectively with appropriate body language.
Be composed with positive attitude.
Understand the core competencies to succeed in professional and personal life.

syllabus.title: Analytical Thinking and Communication Skills
syllabus.topics: Self-Introduction, Shaping Young Minds (Listening Activity), Self–Analysis, Developing Positive Attitude, Perception; Verbal Communication, Non Verbal Communication (Body Language).

syllabus.title: Self-Management Skills and Etiquette
syllabus.topics: Anger Management, Stress Management, Time Management, Six Thinking Hats, Team Building, Leadership Qualities; Social Etiquette, Business Etiquette, Telephone Etiquette, Dining Etiquette.

syllabus.title: Standard Operation Methods and Verbal Ability
syllabus.topics: Note Making, Note Taking, Minutes Preparation, Email Letter Writing; Synonyms, Antonyms, One Word Substitutes, Correction of Sentences, Analogies, Spotting Errors, Sentence Completion, Course of Action, Reading Comprehension.

syllabus.title: Career-Oriented Skills
syllabus.topics: Group Discussion, Mock Group Discussions, Resume Preparation, Interview Skills, Mock Interviews.

reference_books: Mitra, B. K., Personality development and soft skills (Vol. 156). Oxford University Press, 2011.
Dhanavel, S. P, English and Soft Skills. Orient Blackswan Pvt Limited, 2011.
Aggarwal, R. S., A Modern Approach to Verbal & Non Verbal Reasoning. S. Chand, 2018.
Meenakshi, R. & Sharma, S, Technical Communication Principles and Practice, Oxford University Press, 2011.

course_outcomes: Understand the basics of writing technical reports, technical sentence formation, using transitions, and appropriate tenses for technical writing.
Understand the use of drafts, illustrations, grammar, spelling, readability, and writing in plain English for effective technical documentation.
Apply the use of word processor tools such as Table of Contents, citations, footnotes, comments, macros, and document protection.
Understand the nature of Intellectual Property and explain the process of patenting and international cooperation on Intellectual Property.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Technical Writing
syllabus.topics: An introduction to writing technical reports, technical sentences formation, using transitions, using tenses. Planning and Structuring: Planning the report, identifying reader(s), Voice, Formatting, Sections of a technical report, Minutes of meeting writing.

syllabus.title: Drafting and Finalizing Reports
syllabus.topics: The use of drafts, Illustrations and graphics. Final edits: Grammar, spelling, readability and writing in plain English. Proofreading and summaries. Presenting final reports: Printed presentation, Verbal presentation skills, Introduction to proposals.

syllabus.title: Using a Word Processor
syllabus.topics: Adding a Table of Contents, Indexing, Outlines, Comments, Tracking Changes, Footnotes and Endnotes, Inserting citations and Bibliography, Comparing/Combining Documents, Password protection, Using Macros.

syllabus.title: Intellectual Property Rights (IPR)
syllabus.topics: Nature of Intellectual Property: Patents, Designs, Trade and Copyright. Process of Patenting and Development: Technological research, innovation, patenting. International Scenario: International cooperation on Intellectual Property.

textbooks: Kompal Bansal & Parshit Bansal, “Fundamentals of IPR for Beginner’s”, 1st Ed., BS Publications, 2016.
William S. Pfeiffer and Kaye A. Adkins, “Technical Communication: A Practical Approach”, Pearson.
Ramappa,T., “Intellectual Property Rights Under WTO”, 2nd Ed., S Chand, 2015.
reference_books: Adrian Wallwork , English for Writing Research Papers, Springer New York Dordrecht Heidelberg London, 2011.
Day R, How to Write and Publish a Scientific Paper, Cambridge University Press, 2006.

course_outcomes: Understand the basic concepts of compiler phases.
Apply top-down and bottom-up parsing techniques for a given grammar.
Apply syntax directed translation and type checking for a given expression.
Analyze different code optimization techniques and code generation.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Compilers and Lexical Analysis
syllabus.topics: The structure of a compiler, a simple syntax-directed translator. Lexical Analysis: The role of the lexical analyzer, input buffering, specification of tokens, recognition of tokens, the lexical-analyzer generator Lex, finite automata, regular expressions to automata.

syllabus.title: Syntax Analysis
syllabus.topics: The role of the parser, context-free grammars, writing a grammar, top-down parsing (recursive-descent, predictive), bottom-up parsing (shift-reduce, operator precedence), introduction to LR parsing (simple LR, more powerful LR parsers), using ambiguous grammars, the parser generator Yacc.

syllabus.title: Syntax-Directed Translation and Type Checking
syllabus.topics: Syntax-directed definitions, evaluation orders for SDD's, applications of syntax-directed translation, syntax-directed translation schemes. Type Checking: Type systems, specification of a simple type checker, equivalence of type expressions, type conversions.

syllabus.title: Intermediate-Code, Optimization, and Code Generation
syllabus.topics: Intermediate languages, declarations, assignment statements, Boolean expressions, case statements, back patching, procedure calls. Code Optimization: Introduction, the principal sources of optimization, optimization of basic blocks, loops in flow graphs. Code Generation: Issues in the design of a code generator, the target language, addresses in the target code, basic blocks and flow graphs.

textbooks: Alfred V. Aho, Monica S. Lam, Ravi Sethi, Jeffrey D. Ullman, Compilers: Principles, Techniques and Tools, 2nd Edition, Pearson, 2006.
reference_books: Kenneth C. Louden, Thomson, Compiler Construction, 1st Edition, 1997.
Keith D Cooper and Linda Torczon, Engineering a Compiler, 2nd Edition, Morgan Kaufmann Publishers.

course_outcomes: Understand the basic concepts of Cloud Computing.
Apply virtualization techniques for a given application.
Analyze Cloud services and service providers for a given application.
Analyze the concepts of Cloud security for any given application.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Cloud Computing
syllabus.topics: Cloud Computing definition, private, public and hybrid cloud. Cloud types; IaaS, PaaS, SaaS. Benefits and challenges of cloud computing, public vs private clouds, role of virtualization in enabling the cloud; Business Agility, Storing, Managing, and Accessing Data, Performance and Scalability.

syllabus.title: Virtualization
syllabus.topics: Basics of Virtualization - Types of Virtualization - Implementation Levels of Virtualization - Virtualization Structures - Tools and Mechanisms - Virtualization of CPU, Memory, I/O Devices - Virtual Clusters and Resource management - Virtualization for Data-center Automation.

syllabus.title: Cloud Services and Providers
syllabus.topics: Study of Eucalyptus, Open Nebula, Open Stack, and Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google App Engine, Microsoft Azure, Force.com, and Salesforce.com. Cloud storage providers: Amazon S3, Dropbox, Google Drive.

syllabus.title: Cloud Security
syllabus.topics: Cloud Information security fundamentals, Cloud security services, Design principles, Secure Cloud Software Requirements, Policy Implementation, Cloud Computing Security Challenges, Virtualization security Management, Cloud Computing Security Architecture.

textbooks: Rajkumar Buyya, Christian Vecchiola, S. ThamaraiSelvi, Mastering Cloud Computing, Tata Mcgraw Hill, 2013.
Gautam Shroff, Enterprise Cloud Computing, Cambridge University Press, 2010.
Barrie Sosinsky, Cloud Computing Bible, Wiley-India, 2010.
reference_books: Ronald L. Krutz, Russell Dean Vines, Cloud Security: A Comprehensive Guide to Secure Cloud Computing, Wiley-India, 2010.

course_outcomes: Understand the fundamental concepts of cryptography, security, and number theory.
Apply symmetric and asymmetric encryption algorithms for data confidentiality.
Apply cryptographic hash functions and digital signatures for data integrity and authentication.
Analyze real-world network security protocols and standards.

syllabus.title: Introduction and Number Theory
syllabus.topics: Security Attacks, Services, and Mechanisms. A model for network security. Number Theory: Divisibility and the division algorithm, the Euclidean algorithm, modular arithmetic, groups, rings, fields, finite fields, prime numbers, Fermat’s and Euler’s theorems, testing for primality, the Chinese remainder theorem, discrete logarithms.

syllabus.title: Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography
syllabus.topics: Symmetric Ciphers: Classical Encryption Techniques, block ciphers and the data encryption standard (DES), advanced encryption standard (AES). Asymmetric Ciphers: Public key cryptography, principles of public key cryptosystems, the RSA algorithm, Diffie-Hellman key exchange, Elgamal cryptographic system.

syllabus.title: Cryptographic Hash Functions and Digital Signatures
syllabus.topics: Cryptographic Hash Functions: Applications of cryptographic hash functions, secure hash algorithm (SHA). Message Authentication Codes: Message authentication requirements, functions, and codes. Digital Signatures: Digital signatures, Elgamal digital signature scheme, digital signature standard (DSS).

syllabus.title: Network Security Protocols
syllabus.topics: Web Security: Web security considerations, secure socket layer (SSL) and transport layer security (TLS). Email Security: Pretty good privacy (PGP). IP Security: IP security overview, IP security policy, encapsulating security payload (ESP). System Security: Malicious software, viruses and related threats, virus countermeasures, firewalls.

textbooks: William Stallings, Cryptography and Network Security - Principles and Practice, 7th edition, Pearson Education, 2017.
Behrouz A. Forouzan, Cryptography and Network Security, 3rd edition, McGraw-Hill, 2015.
reference_books: Atul Kahate, Cryptography and Network Security, 4th edition, McGraw-Hill, 2019.
Wenbo Mao, Modern Cryptography: Theory and Practice, 1st edition, Pearson Education, 2003.
